19.text:
When Australia separated from Gondwana ages
ago, its animal species were isolated from

25.text:
the rest of the world. Not quite all of them,
though. Birds could still fly between the land masses.

33.text: Giant birds called moas developed in these jungles where food

38.text: was abundant and there were few predators. Some of them weighed as much as 550 pounds.

46.text: This is a distant relative of those birds.

51.text:
This brush-turkey, or pouched talegalla, is
hard at work.

60.text:
A kangaroo is watching him, but the bird is
too busy to notice. These Australian turkeys are anything but lazy.

69.text: The talegalla is polygamous and has to provide

72.text:
a place for his females to lay their eggs.
He's building a very unusual nest.

85.text:
The turkey gathers together leaves and other
plant materials to build his love nest...

96.text:
That's a nest? Yes it is, and some may weigh
as much as four tons.

104.text: "That turkey's got himself quite a job to do"...

110.text: It works like this: The turkey gathers all

112.text:
the leaves he can. Then a fungus grows among
them and they decompose. This process of decomposition

118.text:
produces heat, which turns the nest into a
real incubator.

125.text: The incubator always has to be between 30 and 35 degrees Celsius.

131.text: To take the temperature of the nest, the turkey has  a thermometer in his tongue or in his beak

142.text: And here he is, deep-sea diving in a sea of leaves.

146.text: All in the name of reproduction.

155.text: After a few go-rounds, scientists have decided

158.text:
that evolutionarily
speaking these turkeys are very close relatives

162.text:
of the reptiles since only these birds and
reptiles use this system of heated nests.

175.text: It's a curious case, but whatever it takes to reproduce.

191.text:
And from here I go to Africa where some tribes hunt
in a very unusual way...

208.text:
We're in Borgou, in northern Benin between
Nigeria and Togo, home of the Bariba and Betamaribe

215.text:
groups of the Somba people, one of Africa's
oldest tribes.

225.text:
Formerly hunters, today they also grow crops
and keep livestock, but hunting is still more for them than just a way to acquire food.

240.text: They hunt in small groups led by a chief.

244.text:
Their arrowheads are treated with Strophanthus,
a deadly poison that they get from a plant.

261.text:
Once a year, in May, a number of tribes come together
for the hunt. The hunters set out from their

268.text: different villages playing their flutes and beaded rattles.

277.text: The Council of Elders selects a meeting place. The hunt is very important for the Somba people.

284.text: They hunt to eat... and to demonstrate their courage and intelligence.

293.text:
Special powers are attributed to the hunters, particularly to the chiefs, who have the ability
to neutralize the animals

300.text:
that they are goingto hunt. When everything is ready, they'll
give the order to set out.

310.text:
No one knows how long they will be in the
bush, and the hunt may sometimes last for weeks.

330.text:
Of all the Somba groups they have the most ingenious hunting
techniques.

340.text:
They hunt antelopes, zebras, monkeys, elephants,
buffalo and all kinds of birds.

351.text: This camouflaged hunter moves silently across the land. He knows the terrain and the behaviour of his prey intimately.

360.text: If luck smiles on them and they take down a large animal,

362.text:
they will carry it back home
to cut into pieces and share all around.

367.text:
Forest rangers allow the Bariba to hunt, but not
so the poachers who use rifles rather than

373.text:
arrows and sell ivory and tusks on the black
market.

381.text:
There are both responsible and irresponsible
hunters.

385.text: And from here to the Caribbean.

388.text: In addition to its gorgeous beaches, the Caribbean island of Cuba has other less-known features such as this mangrove swamp.

395.text: The word mangrove comes from a Guaraní word meaning "twisted tree".

400.text: Under water, mangrove roots look like a twisted mass of vegetation. The many roots stabilize the sand and mud.

414.text:
Ocean water and fresh water mix here. The
mix is full of nutrients, fish and crustaceans.

420.text:
Plants have adapted to the lack of oxygen
and easily reproduce, turning the swamp's floor into a tangle of vegetation.

436.text: The area under the water is a labyrinth and above the surface it's an aquatic jungle.

441.text: Many other leafy and woody plants thrive in addition to the mangroves.

451.text: This is a habitat for great quantities of vegetation, and many animals as well.

455.text: A snake slithers along a mangrove limb.

458.text: Is he looking for some eggs for breakfast or for a distracted rodent for an appetizer?

482.text:
These mangroves develop in a very individual
fashion. Their seeds are long and pointed

488.text: and when they drop they have several options.

496.text: They may float away, germinate, or grow roots to sink into the swamp floor.

511.text: It looks very peaceful here... but it's not.

517.text: To birds, the mangrove swamp seems like a peaceful place to nest, especially if they eat fish.

536.text:
Many animals live off the mangrove's leaves
and fruit.

539.text:
I'm looking carefully for anything that moves
in the treetops and anything that may emerge from under the water...

560.text: This is a Cuban or Desmarest's hutia. And this is a boa.

565.text: And these floating tree trunks... with eyes... are mangrove crocodiles.

583.text: I'm in Peru, in these rugged mountains full of vegetation, of cliffs and mountain streams.

589.text: We're looking for city of the clouds, where the Chachapoyas live.

606.text: It more a fortress than a city. A fortress at an altitude of 9,850 feet.

613.text: The wall is 2,000 feet long. I walk its length, amazed and somewhat seasick ...

629.text: It's rectangular, built on a base of limestone, and covers an area of 15 acres.

644.text: How could this city have been inhabited by the Cloud Warriors, light-skinned

648.text: and handsome Indians said by Spanish chroniclers to have been exceptionally stubborn and courageous?

654.text: They were not only courageous but also unconquered

657.text:
until the Incas cut off their supplies of
food and water. Even then the Chachapoyas

661.text: held out for months before they surrendered.

669.text: Inside the walls, Kuelap is a city of roundhouses with unusual conical roofs.

691.text: As we approach the innermost enclaves of the Chachapoyas and their cliffside tombs, the atmosphere turns otherworldly... and supernatural

704.text: More than 100 mummies have been found at the sacred mountain cliffs of La Petaca. The atmosphere here is surreal.

712.text: How did they bury their dead on these inaccessible cliffs? We have no idea; it's hard to imagine...

722.text:
Nevertheless, the mummies
are perfectly preserved, if a mummy can be considered perfect that is.

734.text: The sarcophagi of Karajia contain many Chachapoya mummies.

739.text:
The secrets of these statues that
gaze off into space are another mystery that

743.text:
has yet to be explained. They are a real challenge
to archaeologists and to me they are inexplicable.

752.text: There are those who say that these handsome Indians had European origins...

769.text:
A Spanish lagoon called Villafáfíla also
holds many secrets.

776.text:
Every year it is visited by migratory birds
that pass through here on the way to Extremadura and Andalusia.

794.text: I had never heard the expression "whoop like a crane", but it's common if you spend any time with ornithologists.

801.text: And indeed the birds do call loudly when they sight the lagoon.

807.text: I thought it was from joy, but from what I've seen they do it in order to stay together.

815.text: About a thousand cranes stop over here for several weeks. They find everything they need, especially food in the form of plant stems,

824.text:
small animals and tasty bulbs.
When autumn ends they'll again take flight

829.text:
to spend the winter in Extremadura and Andalusia.
But cranes aren't the only ones to visit Villafáfila.

843.text:
Naturalists, a few tourists and the simply
curious also come here at the end of September

851.text:
when the sky is full of wild geese.
These migrants began to visit us here in 1975.

857.text:
Why 1975? We don't know. At first there were
just a few individuals, but word must have

864.text:
gotten around because now there are nearly
23,000.

868.text:
Geese are very unusual in that they choose
their mates for life. Even if their mate dies

874.text:
they never remarry. Instead they become solitary.
Who would have thought that of a goose?

882.text:
They eat grains and seeds and have plenty
of food.

892.text:
Flying on...
those who continue the journey will fly south

901.text:
to the marshes of the River Guadalquivir.
The bustard also likes to hibernate here.

912.text:
It is 
the largest terrestrial bird in Europe. In
Villafáfila, there is a stable colony of

929.text:
about 2, 000 bustards.
The male is considerably larger than the female

932.text:
--something common to many species-- and weighs
about 40 pounds. That's why it flies only

933.text:
short distances and if it can't fly, it runs.
Spanish bustards find everything they need

938.text:
in this area, so they don't migrate. They
have thoroughly adapted to this countryside

941.text:
and to this salt water lagoon.
When spring comes, the bustards begin their

951.text:
courtship. They divide up into two groups:
males on one side and females on the other.

961.text:
The males display their attributes, above
all their white feathers, and the more the

964.text:
better... hoping that a female will show interest.
While the females consider their options,

967.text:
the male will take flight in order to fluff
up his wings...

968.text:
Like a crane lifting off for a long journey...
Thre are many tribes in Papua New Guinea that

974.text:
had no contact with white men until 1935...
Here in the Highlands, neighbouring tribes

978.text:
have not always got along.
In fact, sometimes they get along very badly,

979.text:
and there are constant battles and wars among
them.

983.text:
These men belong to a tribe known as the Asaro
mud men.

989.text:
The Asaro take advantage of the idea that
guile may win out over brute force, particularly

1000.text:
when their warlike neighbours believe in ghosts
and spirits.

1004.text:
Most of these tribes believe in the spirits
of the dead, in supernatural beings that live

1010.text:
in the forest, and in other spirits called
tomia that inhabit objects and may bring on

1016.text:
bad luck.
The mud men's defense is a frightening mask.

1024.text:
Here they are forming them out of mud. They
believe that these terrifying masks saved

1027.text:
their ancestors from a sure death.
Some of them smear their masks with clay.

1046.text:
This seems to work well because in addition
to camouflaging the mud it does wonders for

1055.text:
and place the masks on their heads.
Some pig's teeth add to the disguise...

1076.text:
And finally, a second layer of a different,
more watery mud.

1091.text:
This trick had its origins in an old man named
Pukiro who had a dream about some monstrous

1102.text:
beings...
The village was besieged by a large enemy

1109.text:
tribe. Inspired by his dream, Pukiro ventured
into the forest when the sun went down with

1115.text:
a mud mask over his head and long claws made
of bamboo shoots. When the enemy saw him emerging

1125.text:
from the darkness they fled in terror.
It' doesn't surprise me...

1131.text:
They may look like carnival revellers in the
light of day but in the forest at night they

1137.text:
look like ghosts... and cunning wins out over
force.

1141.text:
It's easy to be surprised in the Caribbean
as well. The word cenote comes from the word

1167.text:
dzonot in the language of the Mayas. Cenotes
are found in Yucatan, Florida and Cuba.

1173.text:
Cenotes are filled with fresh water filtering
in through surrounding limestone.

1174.text:
This is a cenote on the island of Cuba. It's
connected to the sea by a series of caves.

1180.text:
At first the water was half fresh and half
salty but as time passed it got less and less

1190.text:
salty and the creatures that inhabit it had
to adapt.

1192.text:
They are strange creatures indeed.
This one is a Cubanichthys, but it's easier

1194.text:
to call it a blind fish. These exotic fish
live in permanent darkness. They have no pigment

1202.text:
and no eyes, since there is almost nothing
to be seen where they live. Not much is known

1210.text:
about them...
Although they are blind, they have nothing

1212.text:
to fear.
We do know that there are four species of

1216.text:
blind fish... Their appearance is otherworldly,
but that's simply an adaptation as always.

1220.text:
Their ancestors were nocturnal and had kidneys...
but they gradually adapted to this fresh water

1226.text:
habitat. But they haven't been studied in
depth.

1235.text:
There they go with their dorsal fins to look
round a bit at the bottom of the cenote.

1246.text:
There's barely any light here, and hardly
any predators ...

1251.text:
But there's food. This is a shrimp, a delightful
appetizer for the Cubanichthys...

1262.text:
Although the fish can't see, it detects signals
sent out by the shrimp. Like a pale shadow

1267.text:
it slowly glides toward its prey, safe in
the knowledge that it won't be swallowed in

1271.text:
a moment of carelessness.
Here time doesn't exist. The cenotes hold

1277.text:
great quantities of fresh water, sometimes
in the open and sometimes in deep caves ...

1282.text:
In Yucatan they were sacred places. Some unfortunate
people were unceremoniously thrown into them

1289.text:
from high cliffs and if they didn't die they
were considered gods...

1295.text:
That's not surprising since almost none of
them survived... Human remains have been found

1301.text:
at the bottom of many cenotes...
Of course this was long ago. Today they are

1311.text:
great places for diving. Exploring their depths
is an incredible experience, as long as you're

1318.text: not too disturbed by bones and legends...
